reviewText:
Name: Zenohell
Developer: Team Grybanser Fox
Release Date: 15th October 2015

Old school shoot-em'up
Zenohell is a very cool 90s inspired arcade shoot-em'up that includes very simple game
play, extremely nice looking pixels, alot of content and a soundtrack that sounds
amazing.

Gameplay:

Gameplay in Zenohell is very simple with only dodging, shooting and scoring being the main
features. Controls can be difficult to learn at the start though and may confuse first
time players

Features:

The games graphics are very intriguing and add to the games style and the games 18 track
soundtrack really adds to the overall feel of the game. The game also features a continue
which allows players to carry on from their death point.

Pros:
Cool Graphics
Nice Soundtrack
Classic Gameplay
Alot Of Content
Continue System
Steam Achievements
Cons:
Gameplay Could Get Repetitive After A Few Hours
Confusing Controls
Game Runs In A Low Resolution
Summary:

This is a small and retro game that will keep any age entertained for a good few hours
with nice looking graphics and a great soundtrack.

Rating:

7 / 10

reviewText: This game really scratches that shmup itch! It's very easy to pick up and play, and you can get going within seconds, Aside from all the usual options desired by shmuppers (rotatable screen being the main one), you can also change the music pack used by the game. I haven't tried out the option just yet, but I imagine I could use Cave's music, for example.\n\nI'm not one for longer reviews, but I also want to praise the music and the art, since it becomes immediately clear that a lot of love was put into both these aspects. It feels a bit like I'm playing an Amiga game, and this is high praise in my book.
voteText: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: For anyone in the SHMUPs community, shmups.system11.org, you know I was a tester for this since WAY back over a year ago.  You may also remember me being one of the people streaming an early build not too long ago and showing off an Arcade full clear. It's remarkable to see how much this game has grown since it's origins and the journey was fun.\n\nThis game really does hail back to a time when things were more simple without a crazy tedious scoring system that may drive oneself to madness.  It's fun, easy to get into, yet still hectic when playing to break scores, while offering enough variety in ships and modes to not be put down after one go.  If you like games where you see your score climb to stupid high amounts on an exponential scale, this can make you smile. Also, make note that your bombs are tied both to survival and to scoring.  Throw everything together and it should make for an interesting combination to see what everyone pulls off...

reviewText:
Product received for free

Provided by Giveaways Reborn
Zenohell is a fast-paced bullet hell space shooter in a 16-bit style.

PresentationThe graphics are spot-on, looking exactly like something that would have come out for the Sega Genesis/Mega Drive or the Turbo Grafix 16/PC Engine. The sound effects are great, except for the shooting sound effect of the player's ship, which is essentially just a click, but it's usually so buried under other sounds that it doesn't really matter.

The music sounds fantastic and really fits in with the fast-paced and chaotic gameplay, but it was kind of disappointing in that it didn't really fit with the whole 16-bit aesthetic, so instead of sounding like a midi from a Sound Blaster or anything that would have come out of a 16-bit system, it sounds like modern electronic music (which it is).

ControlsOn a keyboard, the game controls quite nicely, using the standard emulator presets of Shift, Z, and X as the action buttons and the arrow keys for movement. The use of Shift as one of the action keys feels awkward at times, but it's nothing a quick rebind can't fix.

Using a controller, the joystick controls to move the ship feel quite jerky, with the ship only moving in eight directions, while the joystick, of course, moves in all 360 degrees. The action buttons don't work on first time startup, and must be manually bound using the options menu.

PlotThe plot in this game is negligible. It is the standard aliens are attacking! Save us!" Of course
date: plot isn't the main draw for this game.\n\nGameplayThe gameplay is fast-paced and simple. The goal
hoursPlayed: is to shoot all of the bad guys. To do this
voteText: the player has a choice between multiple ships
helpfulPercent: each of which plays differently. The main difference between the ships is their shot patterns
votesFunny: can drastically change the way the game is played.\n\nThe player is given three weapons: the basic shot
commentsCount: a bomb that clears the screen of enemies' shots and gives the player invincibility for a short time
column16: and a "focus shot" which is the basic shot
column17: but slightly more powerful.\n\nThe fast-paced nature of the game makes it quite difficult to dodge enemy projectiles
column18: which seem to be everywhere. This challenge is what makes the game
column20: since the enemies are really quite easy to defeat simply by holding down the shoot button.\n\nThere is a subtle strategy to using the bombs
column21: since the player is only given three at the beginning of the level and there is no way to replenish them.\n\nThe game allows for infinite continues
column23: because it is ridiculously difficult at times.\n\nReplayabilityThe game is essentially an arcade game
column24: and always has the incentive of trying to get a higher score (or not use continues).\n\nConclusionZenohell is a bullet hell shooter
column27:
is thoroughly enjoying and does what it sets out to do.

reviewText:
Retro style Shoot em' up with simple mechanics
Zenohell reminded me of some of the games I used to play in the arcade when I was a kid, such as 1941. The game uses similiar mechanics; eliminate all enemies on screen, while at the same time avoiding the constant barrage of enemy projectiles filling the screen. The gameplay is similar to the classic shoot em' ups, where you have to avoid enemy projectiles while also trying to gain the most points possible. The game gives you three ships to choose from, each with different patterns of fire, and stats. This gives the game variety, and adds some extra challenge. Zenohell stays true the genre and is definitely worth playing if you enjoyed games of the 90s shoot em' up genre.

PROS
Fun, engaging gameplay
Different ships gives gameplay variety
Fun Bosh Rush mode
Stays true to genre
Music reminiscent of older shmups
Simple, easy to learn controls
Visuals resemble that of classic shoot em' ups
CONS
Too short; I completed the first gamemode within 30 minutes
Bosses lack variety
Enemy patterns are often too similar
Summary:
This game is perfect for those who miss the shoot em' ups of the 90s, or people new to the genre willing to give it a try. I had a lot of fun with this game, although I was disappointed when I finished it so quickly. However the Boss Rush mode is a fun addition to the game, for those who complete the campaign.

Rating:
I'd give Zenohell an 8/10.

reviewText: i love shmups, i almost let this one pass me by. it just didnt look interesting to me. but it was on sale and the reviews seemed pretty positive. the game mechanics and controls are pretty darn good. its fast and frentic, at first i said to myself the graphics are kinda awful, but after playing, you lose sight of that really quickly. too much dodging to just keep up. its a pretty hard game, but once you get the hang of it you start asking yourself how did i ever survive that wave of bullets. its a very satisfying experience.

Boring as hell. After 20 minutes of playing I couldnt remember when was the last time I had played such boring and uninspired game. I picked up many upgrades and couldnt see any difference caused by them. The graphics is ugly as hell. Overall the game might be enjoyable only for some shmup-masohists who crave more and more shmups and never have their hunger satisfied.\n\nUnless you are a shmup-masochist, stay away from this as to a average player, even such who plays and likes shmups, this a complete crap

reviewText:
Boring as boring can be: welcome to Zenohell!

It's forgivable that a one team game doesn't do much effort to animate boss enemies but they forgot to animate the player ship. A clever score system is virtually non-existent.

This game is bad to its core. Ugly, generic and dull.
